title: "Could be integrated" features in France
body:
Hello ,
I use Osmose to integrate open databases in Openstreetmap. 
Examples : 
- school, could be integrated (item 8031)
- pharmacy, could be integrated (item 8211)

For a few months, Osmose has not suggested any feature for integration. 
I could not find any explanation, such as automatic edits or code change, though I may have missed something. 

Is it possible to tell why there are no feature suggested anymore ?

title: Validation rule traffic sign: Unmapped road bump (Germany)
body:
I'm happy about general traffic sign recognition validation.

I noticed the task (8300/34) seems to be not suitable in Germany in general, because there doesn't exist such a traffic sign at all.

item 	8300   -   traffic sign 
class 	34     -   Unmapped road bump
[osmose link for item 8300 and class 34](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/issue/625e2ddd-ab9c-d547-aadc-98a9651432f9)
`traffic_calming=bump`[wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag%3Atraffic_calming%3Dbump) / `hazard=bump`[wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:hazard%3Dbump) / sign: ![Vienna_Convention_road_sign_Aa-7b-V1 svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47290585/226734632-df5eb799-8801-406c-8a6f-6825345a4d37.png) [bump sign commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Vienna_Convention_road_sign_Aa-7b-V1.svg) / [bump sign Category commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Diagrams_of_bump_warning_road_signs)

Therefore maybe there are almost all issue marker false positive cases, because of other wrong recognized signs.
The automatic traffic sign recognition is mostly wrong - instead of the "Unmapped road bump" sign there are other signs recognized, eg. sign: ![Vienna_Convention_road_sign_Aa-7a-V1 svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47290585/226736364-ed387d70-54fb-403b-b6d1-d3d057ab1aa5.png) [uneven road sign commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Vienna_Convention_road_sign_Aa-7a-V1.svg) / [uneven road sign Category commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Diagrams_of_uneven_surface_warning_road_signs)

which is a different tag in OSM, see `hazard=damaged_road`[wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:hazard%3Ddamaged_road)
Example: [osmose map link](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#item=8300&class=34&zoom=18&lat=49.786372&lon=8.597509&level=1%2C2%2C3) / [mapillary link](https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=1034019853800738&focus=photo&lat=49.786514639902&lng=8.5969196073756&z=17)

There are also many wrong cases of recognition by guide plate signs:
sign: ![Zeichen_626-30_-_Leitplatte_(750x500);_StVO_2013 svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47290585/226738474-b4c27e42-6fb2-4116-94fd-281dea745d70.png) / [guide plate sign commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Zeichen_626-30_-_Leitplatte_(750x500);_StVO_2013.svg)
Examples: 
i) [osmose map link](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#item=8300&class=34&zoom=18&lat=50.043098&lon=7.803071&level=1%2C2%2C3) / [mapillary link](https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=198426548766765&focus=photo&lat=50.042887127303&lng=7.8028103869347&z=17&x=0.573130873683308&y=0.7624693471920744&zoom=3)
ii) [osmose map link](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#item=8300&class=34&zoom=18&lat=50.065073&lon=8.220498&level=1%2C2%2C3&issue_uuid=6df9d6c0-db18-e099-d861-fbf7e8768ba7) / [mapillary link](https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=4150310748340732&focus=photo&lat=50.065228350547&lng=8.2199129321687&z=17&x=0.6111848125356545&y=0.6619830825964246&zoom=3)

There are also minor wrong cases of recognition by the following signs:
parking sign: ![Zeichen_314-50_-_Parkhaus,_Parkgarage,_StVO_2017 svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47290585/226740972-2e74a0bd-ef39-44de-b65a-661b91b59d1c.png)  [parking sign commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Zeichen_314-50_-_Parkhaus,_Parkgarage,_StVO_2017.svg)
Example: [osmose map link](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#item=8300&class=34&zoom=18&lat=49.444977&lon=7.773637&level=1%2C2%2C3) / [mapillary link](https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=307120021008240&focus=photo&lat=49.445160187256&lng=7.7728348336074&z=17&x=0.7359780627835698&y=0.4064480925318429&zoom=3)

slope signs:![Vienna_Convention_road_sign_Aa-2a-V1-1 svg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47290585/226741583-aa2ac4e6-e91a-4229-8a8b-8075a4b4be97.png)/ [slope sign Category commons wikimedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Diagrams_of_slope_signs_by_Vienna_Convention)
Example: [osmose map link](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#item=8300&class=34&zoom=18&lat=50.118435&lon=8.083137&level=1%2C2%2C3) / [mapillary link](https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=516086173141353&focus=photo&lat=50.118662930419&lng=8.0826405949118&z=17&x=0.6017226389290127&y=0.6257365760322096&zoom=3)

I don't know if this task works well for other countries, please check before switching off the rule for the entire world.

title: duplicate relations in `osmose_config.py`
Bad mapcss evaluation of tag(X) when used with ||
body:
The following rule:
```css
*[name][name=~/^(?i)(chapel|chapelle|kapelle)$/][tag("building")=="chapel"||tag("amenity")=="place_of_worship"]
```
(from JOSM unnecessary rules) is being parsed as: 

```
if ('amenity' in keys and 'building' in keys and 'name' in keys):
    match = False
    if not match:
        capture_tags = {}
        try: match = ((mapcss._tag_capture(capture_tags, 0, tags, 'name')) and (mapcss.regexp_test(mapcss._value_capture(capture_tags, 1, self.re_7c3e64db), mapcss._tag_capture(capture_tags, 1, tags, 'name'))) and (mapcss._tag_capture(capture_tags, 2, tags, 'building') == mapcss._value_capture(capture_tags, 2, 'chapel') or mapcss._tag_capture(capture_tags, 3, tags, 'amenity') == mapcss._value_capture(capture_tags, 3, 'place_of_worship')))
        except mapcss.RuleAbort: pass
```

It should be parsed as
`('amenity' in keys or 'building' in keys) and 'name' in keys` (or ignore them altogether in the "pre-selection")

Additionally, the capture group should be 2 for the entire `[tag("building")=="chapel"||tag("amenity")=="place_of_worship"]` block, not 2 and 3

-------
~EDIT: fix ready, just awaiting #1740 to be merged so I can edit the tests file without creating conflicts~

title: Validator issue: `turn` order check needs some optimization, when bicycle lanes are involved
body:
It seems the checks for the `turn` order are working well for standard cases.

If there are bicycle lanes included the rules give false positives

Example osm way: 
https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/49600780

The object has tags like:
`lanes=2`
`bicycle:lanes=no|no|designated`
`vehicle:lanes=yes|yes|no`
`turn:lanes=left;through|through;right|through;right`

Don't be confused, because `lanes` only counts lanes for motorizes traffic (without bicycle lanes) and `turn:lanes` includes also turns for bicycle lanes, which are defined by `bicycle:lanes`

The double **through;right**|**through;right** seems correct see mapillary picture for this case:
https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=1138349166656984&focus=photo&lat=51.314952700001&lng=12.374022700001&z=17&x=0.6492136208747495&y=0.7613661670191875&zoom=1.00990099009901


The permalink marker map: https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/map/#zoom=18&lat=51.314805&lon=12.374446&item=3160&level=1%2C2%2C3&issue_uuid=55eafb89-9f7d-5ae7-77de-ae240b839a5d

title: Exempt power=plant relations from Large relation check
body: According to the wiki here: https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:power=plant some wind, solar, and hydro power plants use `type=site`+`power=plant`, and they are often spread across a large area, which flags them as a large relation, for example http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/issue/5e83ffec-fe9a-eac1-9762-bd996bb9d305

title: Item 1210 Class 4 only checks for connection inside admin level 4 borders?
body:
Many ways in [Appenzell Innerrhoden](https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/1686666) are marked with Item 1210 Class 4: Small highway group apart from the main network or with insufficient access upstream.

## Probable Cause
There is no `highway=primary` inside this canton, and the validation seems not to check outside the canton. 

## Probable solution
Maybe the check should not be confined to admin boundaries, or the admin level should be changed.

## Example
Way: [193971383](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/807587822)
Issue: https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/de/issue/a0294c92-42c4-4ce3-63ee-05be45fefd6c

It is connected to a `highway=primary`:
https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/41212227
https://www.openstreetmap.org/directions?engine=graphhopper_car&route=47.42334%2C9.58764%3B47.41120%2C9.62585#map=14/47.4188/9.6087

title: exempt highway=raceway from "One way inaccessible or missing parking or parking entrance" check
body: `highway=raceway` are often not accessible via clearly defined paths for safety reasons, usually they're fenced in and isolated, so they should be exempted from item 1210. See https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/issue/7d0b9977-058d-6c20-8085-48f8d07505d5 for an example

title: Mapcss key not parsed
body:
This rule from unnecessary.mapcss (JOSM)
```css
/* #14256, #15664, #20681 */
way:closed[highway=rest_area][area?],
way:closed[highway=services][area?],
way:closed[aeroway=aerodrome][area?],
way:closed[waterway=riverbank][area?],
way:closed[aeroway=helipad][area?] {
  throwWarning: tr("{0} is unnecessary for {1}", "{2.tag}", "{1.tag}");
  group: tr("unnecessary tag");
  fixRemove: "{2.key}";
}
```
Applied on way https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/926894128 (or https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/98570914 )
```
area	yes 
highway	services 
name	Paterson
```

https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/nl/issue/fb7bf10b-4376-9a97-5120-4c0a19bec84c
https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/issue/8a03e8a6-2c8e-bc26-3576-e112440580a0
Message: `area=yes is unnecessary for {{1.key}}=services`

`{{1.key}}` should be parsed as `highway`

I don't know if this is a regression of the recent mapcss changes or a preexisting issue

title: False positive for camra / camera on pubs
body:
Osmose suggests that "camra=yes" should be changed to camera. For example: https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/issue/ba483f1c-3126-450c-ff0c-c167a000d28a

However this is an incorrect suggestion as "camra" is used on pubs in the UK to indicate it is listed in the Campaign for Real Ale's Good Beer Guide. https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:camra=yes?uselang=en-GB

title: False-positive for tag 'train'
body:
When detecting tag 'train', Osmose currently proposes to replace it by tag 'drain'.
See example below.
This is wrong as 'train' is a valid tag. See https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:train

title: False-positive for name='Rue de la Salle des Fêtes'
body:
Currently, Osmose suggests to add 'amenity=community_centre' when name='Rue de la Salle des Fêtes' or 'Parc de la Salle des fêtes' or similar.
See attached screenshot.
It should do that suggestion only when name='Salle des Fêtes', or name contains 'Salle des Fêtes d' (e.g. 'Salle des fêtes du village').

2022-09-14 04:00:14   analyser_osmosis_highway_deadend.py:284 xml generation

title: debit_cards=yes should be valid
body:
Here's an example: https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/issue/b701acd1-d8f4-0f16-f372-d06b5bb9e549


The key is used all over the place and quite popular with 60,000 uses:

https://taginfo.openstreetmap.org/tags/payment%3Adebit_cards=yes#map

https://overpass-turbo.eu/s/1lAO


The reason I think there should not be an Osmose warning for this is because, at least in every place I've been in America in the last decade, there will be absolutely no indication whether a place takes debit cards versus credit cards: at this point if you have a card with a magnetic stripe that isn't Discover or American Express (aka Visa or Mastercard) then you can assume it will work anywhere on the American continent that accepts magnetic stripes. The payment logo on the door will just say "Visa/MasterCard/etc/etc" and the fact that you can "pay with debit" will be something you find out when you're at the register (or, in many cases, be totally transparent to you if you have a Visa/Mastercard-issued debit card like the vast majority of Americans.)

It used to be that you might see the Maestro logo for MasterCard Debit, or other processing network logos, but lately the only way you'll truly know if some debit network like PLUS or STAR or CO-OP is accepted is to try it: there won't be signage, employees won't know, and even the business owner who signed the contract with the processing firm won't know. I recently set up a credit card processing API with Stripe and have no idea which debit-not-credit networks may or may not be accepted: my assumption and expectation would be that they are, in fact I'd be surprised and upset if any brand failed to work worldwide. I know some processors and businesses explicitly don't support American Express or Discover, but that's it: not accepting Visa/MasterCard Debit and Credit is the same thing as not accepting cards here.

The most accurate tagging scheme to reflect American reality at this point would be `payment:cards=yes` and then further details if desired to clarify interesting situations like `payment:american_express=yes` -- it will be extremely difficult, much harder than determining the octane of gasoline offered or the wifi password or the presence of baby changing tables in all genders of the available restrooms, to determine if a certain business supports Mastercard's Maestro, Visa's PLUS, or any other variants.

The most detailed question you might think about walking in and asking a business is "do you accept debit, credit, amex and discover? What about EBT (government food aid cards?)" and even then "debit and credit" is more a synonym for "pin or signature" than any particular detail about processor brands. Even if I called a national chain like Starbucks or McDonald's and asked "do you accept Maestro Debit at all your locations?" they'd be unable to answer because most locations are franchises that can make many of their own decisions and contracts.

A much more important distinction at this point is whether a business accepts contactless (Apple and Google Pay) and chip (America's new mandatory version of chip and pin) not which debit brand they accept.

I don't know what the situation is outside North America, but within the continent at least I think this tag shouldn't generate a warning. The huge popularity of the tag should be an indicator that it isn't going away anytime soon. If there is any warning, it should probably be towards consolidating the situation into something like cards=yes rather than demanding that we document lots of irrelevant unknowable details.

title: MapCSS bad selector count -> wrong message
body:
Error is in the parsing of mapcss rules in Osmose, specifically this block:
```way:closed[amenity ][area?][!highway],
way:closed[building][area?],
way:closed[landuse ][area?][!highway],
way:closed[leisure ][area?][!highway][leisure!=track][leisure!=slipway],
way:closed[natural ][area?],
way:closed[shop    ][area?] {
  throwWarning: tr("{0} is unnecessary for {1}", "{2.tag}", "{1.key}");
  group: tr("unnecessary tag");
  fixRemove: "{2.key}";
}
```

JOSM counts pseudo class selectors (like `:closed`) as a tag. Hence, if you have `landuse=grass` + `area=yes`, JOSM interprets it as `{0.key} = :closed`, `{1.key}=landuse`, `{2.key}=area`, giving the error `area=yes is unnecessary for landuse`.

Osmose on the other hand only seems to counts the `[...]`-selectors while parsing mapcss rules. Therefore, instead of the supposed error message, Osmose counts as `{0.key} = landuse`, `{1.key}=area`, `{2.key}=highway`, thereby producing the bogus messages `highway (for the rules with [!highway]; nothing otherwise) is unnecessary for area`.

[Example](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/nl/issue/af15ec20-c533-ccc6-7bb2-a3772e1368b6) mentioning to remove highway while no highway is present (but `highway` comes from `[!highway]` being counted as the {2.key}). From rule: `way:closed[leisure ][area?][!highway][leisure!=track][leisure!=slipway],`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1315520/187504032-f715ae80-2df9-436b-861a-1adbf27c6ed3.png)

[Example](https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/nl/issue/67cb579d-e383-2c8f-65e3-6f0e1d034031) where no `[!highway]` exists in the rule. From rule: `way:closed[natural ][area?],`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1315520/187502809-fc3f00e2-93ac-413d-8520-8048d062ff74.png)

_Originally posted by @Famlam in https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/issues/1533#issuecomment-1231959504_

title: False positive for parking:condition:[side] without parking:lane:[side] value
body:
The tests in Highway_Parking_Lane.py reflect the situation before Proposed features/Parking lane conditionals (https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/w/index.php?oldid=2289049) was approved on 2022-01-21. 

This moved the values no_parking and no_stopping for parking:lane=* to parking:condition=*, so a false positive if raised for e.g. parking:condition:*=no_parking|no_stopping, but not for the now deprecated parking:lane:*=no_parking|no_stopping.

title: building relation without building tag
body:
item | 9007
class | 9007001
Detail: http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/it/issue/dece295b-a51c-a96f-5e14-7c106151544b

Uhm, not sure about this one. The Wiki page for [type=building](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Relation:building) doesn't mention that you have to put the building=* tag in the relation itself. Instead it says "This outline must be tagged with building=* ", in which the outline is the building added as a member and mapped as an enclosed way. I suspect this Osmose flag is dated back to the now deprecated [IndoorOSM schema](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Proposed_features/IndoorOSM), in which the building=* tag (and all other building descriptive tags) was put on the relation itself: "A building is represented as a relation within our model".

Maybe someone can double-check?

title: Tags/keys shouldn't be translated

labels.name: If you want it. Do it.

body:
I noticed in some cases tags themselves are translated, i.e. in Dutch:
_"Possible missing traffic_signals:direction tag or crossing on traffic signals"_
Became:
_"Mogelijk ontbreekt traffic_signals:richting tag of kriusing op verkeerslichten"_
(i.e. `traffic_signals:direction` & `crossing` were translated, but shouldn't as they're tag names)

Hence I was thinking: maybe it's an idea to convert all these from (using this example)
```python3
title = T_('Possible missing traffic_signals:direction tag or crossing on traffic signals')
```
To for instance:
```python3
title = T_('Possible missing `traffic_signals:direction` tag or `crossing` on traffic signals')
or
title = T_('Possible missing {0} tag or {1} on traffic signals', 'traffic_signals:direction', 'crossing')
or
title = T_('Possible missing `{0}` tag or `{1}` on traffic signals', 'traffic_signals:direction', 'crossing')
```

Obviously a lot of work and I hope this wouldn't erase good translations?

title: Incorrect turn lanes count with busway linking road
body:
http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/nl/issue/74e8abac-30a4-1c96-ba97-a2a555a932c2

Item: 3160
Class: 1

[Incoming way:](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/574813454)
```
access:lanes=||no
highway=trunk
lanes=3
motorroad=yes
oneway=yes
psv:lanes=||designated
turn:lanes=left;through|through;right|
```

[Outgoing way 1:](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/574813456)
```
highway=trunk
lanes=2
motorroad=yes
oneway=yes
turn:lanes=left;through|through;right
```
[Outgoing way 2:](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/574813455)
```
access=no
highway=busway
oneway=yes
psv=designated
```

(I removed some unimportant values from the above lists)

Osmose reports:
> Bad lanes number or `turn:lanes` before and after this node
> lanes in 3(-0+0), lanes out 2(-0+0)

However, lanes out is 2 (from "outgoing way 1") + 1 (from "outgoing way 2") = 3

I'm unsufficiently experienced with SQL to fix it myself, but it seems that only outgoing motorway_link/trunk_link are counted, but not highway=service/highway=busway (i.e. emergency ways and busways respectively). For [busways](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:highway%3Dbusway#Intersection_Treatment) the wiki explicitly mentions to use highway=busway rather than motorway_link/trunk_link.
https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/blob/master/analysers/analyser_osmosis_highway_turn_lanes.py

title: Turn lanes test producing false positives on semicolon-separated turn lanes
body:
Split-off from #873 by @maro-21 and the comment on #1305 as that issue became a mix-up of several unrelated issues. (The `none`-related part of that issue is fixed with #1305 )

> Osmose points out that `turn:lanes=reverse;left|left|through|through|through;right` is "Bad turn lanes order". Why?
> item: 3160
> class: 31607
> https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/blob/master/plugins/Highway_Lanes.py#L92-L140

----

**Cause**
After a quick translation of i.e. `reverse;left|left|through|through|through;right` to `ul|l|_|_|_r` (where _ is in reality a space, meaning `through` or `none`), the following line converts the `ul` and `_r` to `_`:
https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/blob/32b4113ce0f18ce0fa0d1b3b13781ad642ba8fb8/plugins/Highway_Lanes.py#L121

(To be specific, the `if e[0] != e[-1]` part does so). Thereby producing `_|l|_|_|_`, which is invalid (as now there's a "through"-lane left of a "left"-lane).

----

**Laziest solution**
Check every multiple-turn-lanes (like `reverse;left` and `through;right` in the above example) for the presence of any `left` (`l`); if so, replace *all* its contents by `l`. Then check for the presence of any `right` (`r`), if found, replace it completely by `r`. Else `through` = space.
- [x] Resolves the false positives (in the above example that would become `left|left|through|through|right`) [note: u-turns are replaced later in the code]
- [x] Does find bad turn lanes like `right;through|through|right` (as this becomes `r|_|r`) and `through|right;left|through` (as this becomes `r|l`)
- [ ] Doesn't find bad turn lanes like `left;right|left;right` (as this becomes `l|l`)

----

**Better solution**
After splitting at `|`, sort the contents of each fragment (`ul`, `l`, `_`, `_`, `_r` in the initial example) according to
1. left-turns (and merge_to_right)
2. through (note: `none` cannot be part of a `;`-separated item: `turn:lanes=left|left;none|right` are invalid)
3. right-turns (and merge_to_left)

Then join the fragments and treat it as if each `;`-separated item is a separate lane, i.e. as if `reverse;left|left|through|through|through;right` was `u|l|l|_|_|_|r` (and note `u` gets discarded)

- [x] Resolves the false positives (in the above example that would become `left|left|through|through|right`) [note: u-turns are replaced later in the code]
- [x] Does find bad turn lanes like `right;through|through|right` (as this becomes `_r|_|r`) and `through|right;left|through` (as this becomes `_|rl|_`)
- [x] Does find bad turn lanes like `left;right|left;right` (as this becomes `lr|lr`)

----

**Alternative solution**
Same as the one directly above, but also consider `slight_left`, `sharp_left` and `left` as three (+3x `*right`) separate.
I.e., the sequence must be:
1. merge_to_right
2. sharp_left
2. left
3. slight_left
4. through or none
5. slight_right
6. right
7. sharp_right
8. merge_to_left
- [x] Resolves the false positives (in the above example that would become `left|left|through|through|right`) [note: u-turns are replaced later in the code]
- [x] Does find bad turn lanes like `right;through|through|right` and `through|right;left|through`
- [x] Does find bad turn lanes like `left;right|left;right`
- [x] Does also find erroneous `turn:lanes` like `left|sharp_left|through`
- [ ] Assumes `merge_to_right` and `merge_to_left` will never occur in a way like `left|merge_to_right|through` near a splitting of a road. Alternatively (and maybe better), `merge_to_*` can be dropped here too, because it can theoretically occur everywhere except the "wrong" outer lane ([example](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/815893616)), and already has it's own check here: https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/blob/83e3d93c3b5c9aea39aaa59117427462d7686f46/plugins/Highway_Lanes.py#L118-L120

title: Gas Stations Operator Problem in South Tyrol
body:
Greetings,

I'm a mapper from the bilingual province of South Tyrol (Alto Adige) from Northern Italy. I noticed that there are quite some wrong markers in my province where Osmose wants to update the operator of a gas station, for example this one:

osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/error/6e7c424a-2872-42a5-a6fb-f11cc75dbd97

I noticed that the input dataset correctly contains both the German and Italian Operator name and uses ' % ' to differentiate between them.

Could this be converted to ' - ', the way we split our bilingual names here? The marker should not show up as an issue when the operator already matches, or when it's flipped (`German Operator - Italian Operator` instead of `Italian Operator - German Operator`)

title: Please add "checkpoint" as an object
body:
Source 6391, Item 2110 (missing object kind), Class 21101 (Untagged named object)
https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/errors/?source=6391&item=2110&class=21101#

Osmose gives this error for [checkpoints](https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/6814306461), for example.
According to the [OSM Wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:checkpoint), it's a valid object kind and they do not require additional main tags, like `tourism` or `amenity`.

There are also renderers using this key, like [turistautak.hu](http://turistautak.hu).

title: False positive: Invalid Opening Hours

labels.name: If you want it. Do it.

body:
Invalid Opening Hours:
Osmose does not accept Date format in opening_hours: "mmm dd".
Osmose will interpreted "mmm dd" as: "mmm hh:mm".
Evaluation_tool and JOSM will accept both formats: "mmm d" and "mmm dd".
Evaluation_tool is suggesting by "Warnings solved": "mmm dd" as "best practice".

Examples:

Me: opening_hours = "Jul 01-Mar 14"
Osmose: opening_hours = "Jul 1-Mar 14:00"

Me: opening_hours = "Jan 01 off"
Osmose: opening_hours = "Jan 01:00 off"

https://openingh.openstreetmap.de/evaluation_tool/

Me: opening_hours = "Jan 1 off"
Warnings solved: opening_hours = "Jan 01 off"

Dear all,

Osmose sends out a Level 1 issue "Probably missing tag zone:maxspeed=XX:30, according to the neighborhood" on a road with keys (among others) , hw=residential, bicycle_road=yes, maxspeed=30, source:maxspeed=DE:bicycle_road. For example, here https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/174638684

title: Odd behaviour when using Jupyter Notebooks for testing Analyser_Merge Classes
body:
When creating an analyser_merge using the new Jupyter-Feature, changes to a class after it has been created are not taken into account. It seems like whatever class is first defined gets cached somewhere, and updates to this same class are not taken into account.

1. Open the .ipynb file I uploaded here: [analyser_merge_emergency_points_LU.zip](https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/files/4806515/analyser_merge_emergency_points_LU.zip)

2. Run the cells from top to bottom
3. In the fix-column, you should see an addition for the key "ref".
`{'+': {'ref': 'BB-001', 'highway': 'emergency_..`
4. Now go back into the class definition, and change "ref" to "refX" in static1.
5. Execute the changed class
5. Rerun the analysis
6. - _Expected result:_ instead of "ref" in the result set, we should be seeing "refX".
    `{'+': {'refX': 'BB-001', 'highway': 'emergency_..`
    - _Actual Result:_ The old class definition is still being used. By changing the class name to something else and rerunning the analysis, the "new" refX is added into the result set.
    `{'+': {'ref': 'BB-001', 'highway': 'emergency_..`


Edit: Improved expected/actual result section.

title: Accept parking:lane:right AND parking:lane:left instead of parking:lane:both
body:
item | 3161
-- | --
class | 31616

### Actual behavior
This plugin checks whether for each `parking:condition:[side]` if tfere is an `parking:lane:[side]` key with the same Value for `[side]`
### Expected behaviour
It should check if for every side of the street where a parking:condition is given if there also is parking:lane for this side of the street. The side may be explicitly given as `right `or `left `or implicitely as a part of `both`
So instead of only checking if both values for `[side]` are the same, it should also be checked if one pair of `right` and `left` in one key matches `both` in the other key.

title: Duplicated values - blacklist couplings:diameters
body:
Problem: http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/cs/error/9bd633b7-5e12-cd80-6d49-e46e6ad60f8e

Actual value is: couplings:diameters = 75 mm;75 mm;110 mm

So it's probably safe to add couplings:diameters to the following blacklist:

https://github.com/osm-fr/osmose-backend/blob/bcc4cc69bb9622c7172ea462daa7c02d966dd1d4/plugins/TagFix_DuplicateValue.py#L48

title: Add support for Canadian postal codes
body:
Canadian postal codes are in the format A1A 1A1, where A is a letter and 1 is a digit, with a space separating the third and fourth characters. That is: regex ^[A-Z][0-9][A-Z] [0-9][A-Z][0-9]$

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_codes_in_Canada

In OSM, if building an postal code area(boundary), then only the first 3 characters are normally listed.
For addresses all 6 characters should be listed, however if for some reason the full postal code is not fully known, then some people only list the first 3 characters.  However, these kinds of postal codes are not complete and should still flag an error.

The Canadian postal code database is not open data.  However, postal codes are added into OSM based on publicly available information, not using the official postal code database.

Incorrect opening_hours correction suggestion

labels.name: If you want it. Do it.

body:
Hi,

See https://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/map/#item=3250&zoom=17&lat=48.834572&lon=2.351347&level=1%2C2%2C3&tags=&fixable= , there is an `opening_hours` error reported on https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/161119956. The current `opening_hours` value is

> Tu-Su 11:00-18:00; Dec 25 off; Jan 01 off; May 01 off; Dec 31 11:00-17:00

It however seems to be valid according to https://projets.pavie.info/yohours/?oh=Tu-Su%2011:00-18:00;%20Dec%2025%20off;%20Jan%2001%20off;%20May%2001%20off;%20Dec%2031%2011:00-17:00. I did not dig very much in the details of this syntax to find out whether this is a false positive or not, yet.

The main issue is that the proposed fix is:

> opening_hours = Tu-Su 11:00-18:00; Dec 01:00 off; Jan 01:00 off; May 01:00 off; Dec 31 11:00-17:00 

which transforms "25" and "01" as days into hours ("01:00"), which is an error.

Thanks!
Best,

title: parking=yes/no doesn't need an amenity=parking
body:
parking=yes is often used (>3000) to describe that a poi (hotel, restaurant, camp_site, camp_pitch) has its own parking.
and parking=no is used to describe that a poi does not have its own parking.
I think that osmose should not consider as an anomaly the fact of having an amenity/shop/tourism/office=* with parking=yes/no.
on the other hand amenity=parking parking=yes/no is indeed an error and must continue to be reported (455 cases currently)

title: opening_hours: 24
body:
Is there a guideline on hour value above 23?
[OH wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:opening%20hours?uselang=en-US ) says "HH: An absolute 2-digit hours number (in day, in 24h format, no am/pm) in range 00-23", yet the same page uses example: "Sa-Su 00:00-24:00".  Personally, I find "00:00-24:00" more readable.  Our current implementation proposes to change  "00:00-24:00" to "00:00-00:00" (thus many false positives).

[evaluation_tool](https://openingh.openstreetmap.de/evaluation_tool/#check) allows values over 23 and does not change them.  Should we do the same, or only change values over 24?

_amenity=bicycle_parking:_

For now, please ignore my other issue (OFF TOPIC):
Mapillary "Street object ****" is responsible for too many false positives.

title: False positive : Tag "addr:street" not matching a street name around
body:
This issue happens for all addresses on squares/plazas/... which are highways tagged with `area=yes`.

For example this plaza in Montpellier : http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/map/#zoom=18&lat=43.599254&lon=3.897137&item=2060

My understanding is that this false-positive is because anything with `area=yes` gets excluded from the "highways" DB in `Analyser_Osmosis.py` , meaning that the later `Analyser_Osmosis_Relation_AssociatedStreet` can't match the addr:street against anything.

 The problem is that the historical way to mark pedestrian squares was to use `highway=pedestrian, area=yes` ... meaning that all addresses on that square will be marked as false positives.

While excluding "area" highways makes sense, would it make sense to also allow (whether area or not), the highways with `place=square` in the ways DB of `Analyser_Osmosis.py` ? Or would that be too disruptive and instead add that additional check in `Analyser_Osmosis_Relation_AssociatedStreet` ?

title: False positive: amenity=bench Street object bench observed around but not associated tags
body:
False positive: 
"amenity=bench Street object bench observed around but not associated tags".

Mapillary shows "Street object", but most of them are not "amenity=bench", but:
- gate (mostly: wooden gate as found in the country side)
- shadow of a gate on the grass
- traffic_barrier
- railing ("fence=railing" or "railing" on a building or bus shelter).

I also notice a lot of Mapillary images referred to by Osmose in which I cannot find a "bench" being marked as such by Mapillary. In some of these Images I do see a "bench", but that one is not marked as "bench". Wondering which "bench" is being referred by Osmose.

A "bicycle parking" is not always a "bicycle_parking", but - sometimes - a "barrier=cycle_barrier" or just a "fence".

And yes, some benches are indeed missing on OSM. However, even some of those are "private" (located in front of a private house). Therefore not mapped (by me).

False positives (like "opening_hours"!) on Osmose are not harmless:
- distracting
- covering real errors
- demotivating
- acting on a false positive might result in a real error!
F.i. change "barrier=cycle_barrier" into "amenity=bicycle_parking"
- I prefer benches not on OSM (most likely I won't even notice in real life) to benches on OSM, but not "on the ground". 
- bad for Osmose image and might even result in ignoring Osmose by some OSM-mappers. 

I don't think Mapillary "streets object" are - in this state - useful for Osmose "Error" detection.
Specially since I notice tens of false positives in a small circle.
Location: Woerden, The Netherlands.

title: French postal codes and Osmose : which tagging?
body:
Hi,

I'm puzzled with the way Osmose signals issues with postal codes in France...

Please have a look on these two neighbouring villages:
Lourches: https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/56082#map=14/50.3110/3.3411
Rœulx: https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/56093#map=14/50.3110/3.3411

The postal code of the former is tagged with "postal_code". It is signalled by Osmose by 2 issues: http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/fr/error/26517612431, http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/fr/error/26517611530 . "So far so good, then, change the tag postal_code to addr:postcode!" But...

The latter is tagged with addr:postcode, and Osmose still signals it! http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/fr/error/26496525511

So, what is the good practice for tagging postal codes? From what I see from Overpass in my region, it looks like addr:postcode is mostly used in France... and postal_code in Belgium :s 
addr:postcode : https://overpass-turbo.eu/map.html?Q=%2F*%0AThis%20has%20been%20generated%20by%20the%20overpass-turbo%20wizard.%0AThe%20original%20search%20was%3A%0A%E2%80%9Cboundary%20and%20addr%3Apostcode%E2%80%9D%0A*%2F%0A%5Bout%3Ajson%5D%5Btimeout%3A25%5D%3B%0A%2F%2F%20gather%20results%0A(%0A%20%20%2F%2F%20query%20part%20for%3A%20%E2%80%9Cboundary%20and%20addr%3Apostcode%E2%80%9D%0A%20%20relation%5B%22boundary%22%5D%5B%22addr%3Apostcode%22%5D(49.62316641036844%2C2.6477050781249996%2C50.89263913111063%2C4.36431884765625)%3B%0A)%3B%0A%2F%2F%20print%20results%0Aout%20body%3B%0A%3E%3B%0Aout%20skel%20qt%3B

title: s/amenity=dancing_school/leisure=dance + dance:teaching=yes
body:
Hello,

- http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/fr/error/23618228015

clé | valeur
-- | --
source | 5833
item | 8170
class | 88
subclass | 1419197878
title |  fr Terrain de sport non intégré Salle de danse

Correction | clé | valeur
-- | -- | --
tags_create | amenity |  dancing_school

- Sauf que : abandonné (2010) : https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Proposed_features/Dancing_school

- Donc : "Please use leisure=dance + dance:teaching=yes instead." (https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:amenity%3Ddancing_school)

HTH

title: Conflict between tags: leisure, natural: marina with water
body:
● 4030 incompatible tags → Conflict between tags: leisure, natural
• http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/map/#zoom=16&lat=52.84983&lon=5.684&item=0000%2C0001%2C4030&level=1%2C2%2C3&tags=&fixable=

• http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/errors/?country=netherlands_friesland&item=4030&level=1

With an **area** tagged as leisure=marina **and** natural=water this is marked as "incompatible tags".
But in a harbour without water is hard to navigate.
The standard OSM renders a marina without water as dry land.
Therefore I consider this as a false positive.

title: "Object must be close to coast or water" man_made=pier in or near multipolygon
body:
● 1221 far from water
● http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/errors/?country=netherlands_flevoland&item=1221&level=1%2C2%2C3
● http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/map/#zoom=17&lat=52.839807&lon=5.707397&item=1221&level=1%2C2%2C3&tags=&fixable=

When the a man_made=pier is in or near water of type=**multipolygon** then this object is marked.
In my opinion this is false positive.

title: False positive "Discordant maxspeed and source:maxspeed" in Poland.
body:
Tagging that road has rural speed limit is done in many ways.

1. Explicit tagging of maxspeeds
1. Explicit tagging of maxspeeds and symbolic value `Pl:rural` in `source:maxspeed`
1. symbolic value `Pl:rural` in `maxspeed`
1. at least one more system

This is messy and hairy and there is plenty to complain but in http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/error/22358635600 there is no valid reason to complain about "Discordant maxspeed and source:maxspeed"



highway | residential |  
lit | no |  
maxspeed | 90 |  
maxspeed:bus | 70 |  
maxspeed:hgv:conditional | 90 @ (weight<=3.5); 70 @ (weight>3.5) |  
maxspeed:trailer | 70 |  
noname | yes |  
source:maxspeed | PL:rural |  
surface | asphalt

title: False positive in "Duplicated similar values" for explicitly tagged maxspeed in Poland
body:
Note: while maybe tagging `maxspeed=PL:rural` may be preferable this way is tagged correctly. Number of cases is ridiculous, but it is not fault of mapper.

http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/en/error/22358635443

> Duplicated similar values maxspeed:hgv:forward:conditional=90 @ (weight<=3.5); 70 @ (weight>3.5)

This complaint is invalid and can not be solved.

title: opening hours parser is incomplete and produces lots of false positives

labels.name: If you want it. Do it.

body:
I would suggest disabling the check globally as it is far from correct and highlighting lots of issues with perfectly good OH strings.

Example: it complains about opening_hours = Mo-Sa 07:00-19:00; PH Su off 

Which is perfectly OK, see https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:opening_hours/specification#explain:weekday_selector

Note: it is likely that the mapper in question actually should have used PH,Su but that is not the point. 

Other example: the relatively commonly used weekday in month syntax is completely missing from the BNF for the parser in OSMOSE.

See https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:opening_hours/specification#explain:weekday_range:nth_entry

body:
False positives: Small highway group apart from the main network or with insufficient access upstream
All warnings are having "High severity".

These false positives are "blurring" the real issues.

All ways are:
- [highway=service], [service=driveway]

title: False positive: Small highway group apart from the main network or with insufficient access upstream
body:
"Small highway group apart from the main network or with insufficient access upstream" is a correct warning for non-routable highways.
Keep Right: "This way is not connected to the rest of the map".

But in case of an island this is a very incorrect warning. All highways on an island are having a false positive!
By the way: the island does have - routable - access by ferry boat!

title: Germany: highway=livingstreet and maxspeed=walk
body:
In Germany, walk speed has no certain value. You cannot say that in Germany walk speed is 7 km/h or 5 km/h or whatever. So in OSM on a living_street there cannot be a maxspeed=7 or maxspeed=5. maxspeed=walk would be ok. I hope I made everything clear.

So highway=livingstreet and maxspeed=walk would be in in Germany, every else maxspeed=* with a certain value not.

title: Multiple false-positives for #5030 error
body:
From WiKi:

> Details
Le tag name=* contains two street names, separated by a semicolon, a "/" or a "\". This issue was probably produced by the fusion of two way and the concatenation of the names of streets.

So, the error should be reported for streets. However, such amenities as kindergarten and school are represented by areas which are basically closed ways with corresponding tags. And in Belarus, for example, we have a convention of naming kindergartens like this "д/с №321" [(convention)](http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/WikiProject_Belarus/%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%8A%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D1%8B).

And now all kindergartens named by convention have the 5030 error attached:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3897579/32568014-1de16560-c4ce-11e7-8e2b-75be512bb024.png)

Is it possible to make sure that analysis is done on streets only?

title: Unfinished line on T connections (power 7040 class 2)
body:
Hi,
Some osmose tests look for unfinished linear features (like power lines, item 7040 class 2);
There are currently numerous false positive results, like this one : http://osmose.openstreetmap.fr/fr/error/13394096365

Osmose seems to look for the end of a line without proper tags, without checking for a connection to an equivalent feature.
The problem may occur in other similar tests
